This is a topic that is very near to my heart. I teach at a small rural school in Lee County, Va., but my grandfather, grandmother, father, mother, aunts, uncles, and brothers all work for our local newspapers (it's family owned).  That particular newspaper has been established since 1920s. But even my family and I realize that local papers are almost impossible to maintain in rural areas for many reasons (size of readership, moving to digital content, larger papers (looking at you NYT), shrinkage of ad revenue, etc.) I don't know how long our papers will continue, but we all see the writing on the wall. 

A local paper does so much to check and inform its community. I know it's not exciting to post a water rate hike, or a change in zoning from residential to commercial, but those are the things that impact directly on the people. Without those postings that are required, there can be corruption without anyone knowing what is going on. Your graph makes it obvious that many rural places have no local news. 

I've grown up in a paper family. It's a thankless job a lot of the time. But some of my fondest memories are about putting a paper to bed and delivering them with my dad around our county.
